reviewText: Here Come The Brides was my favorite show growing up, and I was afraid it was destined to the realm of trading poorly-recorded vcr tapes. But now this wonderful news!HCTB has excellent scripts, perfect casting, and wonderful background music; it seamlessly blends humor, or poignancy, with its adventures.  But the show's greatest strength is the uniqueness of the Seattle residents, and their relationships with each other.The shy courtship between Swede and Miss Essie, the playful, mature friendship of Lottie and Captain Clancy, the fierce loyalty between the three Bolt Brothers... and most especially, the sweet love story that is Candy and Jeremy... they are what make Here Come The Brides such a joy.Thank you, Sony!

reviewText: This was my favorite show when it was on originally.  I always remembered it fondly but sometimes memories make us recall something as better than it was.  Not in this case.  This show is even better than I remembered!  The acting isn't cheesy as it is in so many older shows.  It is really a great family show with so many more things to appreciate now that I'm older than just how cute Bobby Sherman is.  Although, that is still the case!  I really hope they release the second season.  It's too bad the show wasn't on longer.  Lucky for us the number of shows in a season back then was twice what it is today.

reviewText: "Here Come the Brides" (oh, that name!) was a series that should have run for years; it was a completely captivating blend of action, adventure, romance, humor, and the '60s approach to 'relevance', with a top-notch cast. Sadly, poor scheduling, and a studio reshuffling that placed less supportive executives in charge, ended the show after just two seasons...but seeing it finally on DVD will allow a whole new generation to discover how good it truly was!Based, loosely, on Asa Mercer's quest to bring marriageable women to early Seattle, combined with elements from "Seven Brides For Seven Brothers" and "Westward, the Women", the series focused on the logging Bolt brothers (brawny, loquacious Robert Brown, level-headed David Soul, and sensitive Bobby Sherman), who, to keep their crew from leaving Seattle, promise to bring in 100 New England women "of good character" to become their brides. Forced to borrow funding for the trip from greedy entrepreneur Aaron Stempel (Mark Lenard), on condition that he would 'own' their mountain if the women don't remain for a year, the series would focus on the adjustment of the women to a new life (particularly the romance between '60s heartthrob Sherman and Bridget Hanley), and the Bolts' continuing confrontations with Stempel.Blessed with a remarkable cast (including legendary Joan Blondell as a saloon owner, Henry Beckman as a crusty sea captain, and Susan Tolsky in comic relief), Season One was certainly the best, both comic and richly human. Yes, the women were clearly more 1960s than 1860s in appearance, with their contemporary hairstyles and make-up, but the stories were generally first-rate, and Robert Brown a magnificent leading man. By Season Two, the series would introduce children in an attempt to broaden it's appeal, but even at it's worst, "Brides" never lost it's charm.Guest stars in Season One included familiar faces (Edward Asner, Monte Markham, Lew Ayres, Will Geer, Rosemary DeCamp), and one rising star whose presence makes this Collection even more desirable to own...Bruce Lee (who didn't use martial arts, but did display the good looks and charm that would soon fill theatres, worldwide).The bouncy theme music ("Seattle"), written by Hugo Montenegro, Jack Keller and Ernie Sheldon, would, by the middle of Season One, include vocals sung by "The New Establishment", which, unfortunately, is never heard in this collection (copyright issues?); the opening in Season Two would be sung by Perry Como, which I hope will be used, as it became a pop hit (Bobby Sherman would also record a successful version). I've been humming it for 40 years, so I admit I love it!"Here Come the Brides - The Complete First Season" is cause to celebrate, reviving a terrific series that is just as much fun today as it was, back in 1968!
summary: Heart, Humor, and Heroics...and a Great Theme Song, too!

reviewText: Here comes the Brides was a simple innocent show. It was a show of limited depth and great heart. It had simple messages, which also had family values...it that good? to me, it isThe story of the Bolt Brothers (Robert Brown, David Soul and Bobby Sherman) who own a logging camp on their mountain in Seatle, Washington. They go east to get 100 Brides for their men. This is to make sure the men do not leave Seattle. The town's leading citzen (Mark Leonard), the one who owns the saw mills, helps front the money for the Brothers to voyage East, holding the Brother mountain as a stake against their  default. What amazed me all three brothers left Seattle to go east, that had a logging business  when then returned, but that is the charm of this piece...and a plot point well forgotten. Well The brides commit to stay a year in seattle and that is the premious of the show.This charming show is pure family entertainment and is totally enjoyable.This series  is almost 40 years old and these simple hour long shows hold up well in both production value and entertainment, just like the older Disney films and TV doesSo is  it worth it? Foe an hour where you dont have car chases, gang violence, or cursing...Sure. For pure Family entertainment the whole family can watch together-SURE...for a simple romantic show that 6-90 can watch and share-SURE..So WHY HAVEN'T YOU BOUGHT THIS YET?Bennet Pomerantz AUDIOWORLD
summary: A nice  family show like Disney and Others use to make

reviewText: I cannot tell you how excited I was when I came to learn that "Here Come The Brides" would be released on DVD.  I used to watch this show when I was a child and missed it terribly when it was canceled. The show was loosely based upon the story of Asa Mercer who had brought a group of young single women from the east to the Pacific Northwest town of Seattle where the population was predominately male.The one part of the show I always remembered for years was in the opening credits where "The New Establishment" were singing the uplifting and inspiring song "Seattle".  Sadly for whatever the reasons, this was reduced to a shortened instrumental version for the DVD.  Aside from this minor flaw, this is a 40 year old wish fulfilled.  Thank You Sony

reviewText: I rejoice at our collective good fortune that Sony is releasing the all-too-short-lived 60's TV smash hit, "Here Come the Brides," on DVD. All 26 episodes that comprised the first season, including the pilot, are included in this six-disc boxed set. The only special feature listed to be included are "bonus previews." This release is even more amazing considering the show has never before been released to the public in ANY format since its initial run!!The show, which aired for only two seasons from 1968-70 on ABC with a total of 52 episodes, launched the careers of teen heart-throbs Bobby Sherman and David Soul. Sherman, who was also a pop singer, became an international superstar predating David Cassidy's Partridge Family mass popularity. (Sherman made news in the 90s when he was certified as an Emergency Medical Technician in Los Angeles.) Soul went on to further TV fame co-starring in Starsky and Hutch (as well as for some later well-publicized legal troubles involving domestic violence charges, etc.)Set in Seattle in the 1870's, the series focused on the travails of the logging Bolt brothers. To avoid losing their male crew, they were forced to agree to bring in 100 prospective brides from Massachusetts, using money they borrowed from sawmill owner, Aaron Stempel. Should any one of the women decide to go home, or should the camp fail to meet Stempel's timber quotas, the Bolts would forfeit their title to the mountain and the business that had been in their family for generations.The core cast includes Robert Brown as eldest brother, Jason Bolt; Soul as middle brother, Joshua Bolt; Sherman as youngest brother, Jeremy Bolt; Mark Lenard as Stempel (and who went on into TV immortality as Sarek, Spock's father, in Star Trek: The Original Series and its later movies, most notably, Star Trek III: The Search for Spock and Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home); the incomparable movie actress Joan Blondell as saloon owner Lottie Hatfield; Bridget Hanley as Candy Pruitt, leader of the "brides" and Sherman's love interest in the show; Susan Tolsky as goofy Biddie Cloom; Henry Beckman as Capt. Roland Francis "Fish-Face" Clancey, Blondell's love interest in the show; and Bo Svenson as Big Swede.In the pilot, to keep their logging crew, the Bolt brothers end up literally betting their mountain to that they can bring 100 marriageable women back to Seattle, which has almost no women in residence, and that those women will remain in Seattle for a year. In exchange, Stempel funds their expenses. Jason Bolt travels to New Bedford, Mass., a town that had a shortage of men at the time, and enlists 100 women for the return trip to the Pacific Northwest. (Ironically, the episode evolved from a script originally intended as a movie musical. Among the stars considered were Burt Lancaster and Shirley Jones, soon of the Partridge Family. According to the Classic TV Archive, the storyline is loosely based on Seattle's history when a resident went to Massachusetts to bring back women to help civilize the Washington Territory, and was NOT based on "Seven Brides for Seven Brothers.")In addition to the pilot, episodes that comprised the first season and that are collected in their entirety in this boxed are (thanks to another reviewer, I have corrected two titles I incorrectly reported): A Crying Need; And Jason Makes Five; The Man of the Family; A Hard Card to Play; Letter of the Law; Lover and Wanderers; A Jew Named Sullivan (not a politically-correct title); A Man and His Magic; A Christmas Place; After a Dream Comes Morning; The Log Jam; The Firemaker; Wives for Wakendo; A Kiss Just for You; Democracy Inaction; One Good Lie Deserves Another; One to a Customer: A Dream that Glitters; The Crimpers; Mrs. and Mrs. J. Bolt; A Man's Errand; Loggerheads; Marriage Chinese Style; and The Deadly Trade.The series also boasted one of the best theme songs ever (which Sherman recorded on his debut album.) The following is the rousing chorus: "The bluest skies you've ever seen, in Seattle, and the hills the greenest green, in Seattle. Like a beautiful child, growing up, free and wild, full of hopes and full of fears, full of laughter, full of tears, full of dreams to last the years, in Seattle. When you find your own true love, you will know it, by her smile, by the look in her eyes...scent of pine trees in the air...look out everyone, Here Come the Brides!"Let us hope that Sony does not keep us waiting too long for the second season DVD boxed set! I'm sure the popularity of this release, and the DVD releases of the Big Valley and the Wild, Wild, West are sending strong messages to studio execs that there is a huge, appreciative and paying audience for vintage TV westerns. Hopefully, The High Chaparral is next in line for DVD release in complete season boxed sets!
summary: The Bluest Skies We've Ever Seen, in Seattle!!

reviewText: I have no idea why it has taken me nearly six years since purchasing my HCTB Season One DVDs to write a review.  Better late than never, I suppose.  I imagine the recent release of Season Two on DVD (thank you, Shout Factory)has prompted me to address my thoughts regarding the first season of this fine show.A quick scan of the more than 200 current reviews shows the general consensus to be overwhelmingly five stars, and I'm not about to disagree.  When I sat down to watch these shows again, after so many years of just remembering it showing on ABC back in 1968-1970, it was like catching up with long-lost friends.  Since the show was already set in a time period 100 years prior to its original run, it really hadn't aged much in the intervening 38 years.  Sure, it was easy to tell it was a product of the late 60s - early 70s, with its sometimes simplistic plot lines and often goofy humor.  But what a refreshing respite from so much of the junk on television today!  I must have watched the entire series in less than a month, and have often re-watched select episodes time and again, patiently waiting for Season Two.Probably the hardest time I had with being a teenaged male fan in the late 60s, was the title of the show itself.  I know now it was pretty shallow on my part, but I somehow found it difficult to admit to my high school football buddies that I watched a TV show called "Here Come The Brides".  It just sounded too "chick" oriented, even though it actually had a much more universal appeal.  I've often thought the show may have had more success and a longer run if it had been called something else.  Maybe "The Loggers and the Ladies"...(just kidding).  Heck, this show made me want to BE a lumberjack (though not the Monty Python kind)...  So I basically went through two years of being a "closet" HCTB fan. Silly, I know.  But my friends could be merciless if they thought they had anything on you at all that they could tease you about.Regarding the DVDs themselves, they look and sound great.  It's a shame they did not include any extra features (something the Season Two DVDs are also woefully short on), but just having this classic series on DVD is a pretty big deal.  I like the slimline cases housing the different discs (actually better than Shout Factory's Season Two packaging), though I don't know where they got the old time photos from.  Certainly not the show.  Are they supposed to be actual scenes of Seattle in years gone by?Speaking of Seattle, I know I'm REALLY late to the party on this, but I must address the issue of the opening credit theme music.  So many reviewers - even some five star ones - are lamenting the lack of the well known vocal version of "Seattle" being used on these Season One DVDs.  Some are even saying the instrumental music used isn't "Seattle" at all, but some inferior generic theme music.  People, trust me - it really IS an instrumental version of "Seattle".  It's the EXACT instrumental music used during the first part of Season One back in 1968-'69.  I had an off the air reel-to-reel recording of it along with the themes from The Wild Wild West, The Avengers, Star Trek, etc.  I loved the instrumental intro, and knew it (and still know it) note for note.  The vocal version of "Seattle" was only introduced part way through Season One, with the familiar lyrics simply being laid down over the existing instrumental track.  It was sung by The New Establishment.  Neither Perry Como's nor Bobby Sherman's versions were ever used on the show.  Unfortunately, I believe they used the instrumental version throughout the entire Season One DVD set, so at least part of these shows have the incorrect version of the theme.  That's the only basis for complaint I can think of.  But hey - it's still "Seattle", just as it was heard in all of the early episodes.  For those of you who have not yet bought the Season Two DVDs, the vocal version IS there.  So enjoy.Lastly, with this DVD now out of print, available copies are commanding ridiculous prices.  It's a shame, but that's what happens so often these days.  Very doubtful that Sony will re-release it, but perhaps if Season Two sells well, Shout Factory can somehow acquire the rights to Season One from Sony, and re-release it.  Only time will tell.
summary: Here Come The Brides - The Complete First Season

reviewText: It's been fun re-discoving this fine series after all these years.  I really don't recall many episodes as HCTB was never syndicated en masse.  Also many families, mine included, didn't yet own a color television set back in 1968.  The series looks as fresh, clean and colorful as the Seattle air of a hundred years ago.  This show is is just a pure delight for the whole family.  You know, this series would be a prime candidate for revival for perhaps FOX or even better, the new CW network coming Fall of 2006.Topping it off, each episode is a whopping ~51.5 minutes long, not counting the opening credits as compared to todays "hour long" show averaging a mere 42.5 minutes.  Now that's entertainment.Also as a big fan of Mark Lenard, it nice to see him play a character with regular emotions as opposed to a Romulan, Vulcan or Klingon alien.  Other Classic Star Trek alumni I've spotted in season one include David Soul, Mark Lenard, Robert Brown, Majel Barrett,(many eps), William Schallert, Michael Forest, Susan Howard & Michael Ansara (same eps) and John Anderson (ST:TNG).

reviewText: I've been waiting for this absolutely wonderful series to show up on DVD!  Co-stars are David Soul (Starsky & Hutch,) Mark Lenard (Star Trek,) Bridget Hanley (Harper Valley PTA,) teen idol Bobby Sherman, the hilarious Susan Tolsky and Henry Beckman, and the fabulous Joan Blondell.  The series' star, Robert Brown, is probably the handsomest actor ever to grace the small screen.Only nitpick I have...no extras on this DVD set?  No interviews, comments, bloopers, or outtakes?  Maybe on Season 2 (hint, hint)!This is a terrific show and well worth seeing...lots of humor, hunks, and heart!

reviewText: I just finished watching the first year series. I would really enjoy getting the second year to complete this series. It is a fun series with wonderful characters and relationships. The stories are very well done. The only complaint is the often exaggerated and sort of fakey costumery & makeup of most women.I wonder where is Puget Sound? Anyway,it is well done story telling. I love Joan Blondell,long before this series. I was raised in the NW and my dad was a logger. It's sort of like the great Northern Exposure series stories with great characters and very innaccurate Alaskan scenes and layouts. I am now an Alaskan of 40+years.:) My family were all pioneers in those eras. It is still good watching and family fare.

reviewText: I remember this series from my childhood.  It was one of my favorites.  I remember dropping my toys in my room and rushing out to the living room to watch the show with my parents just as soon as I heard the theme song sing the words "The blueest skies you've ever seen..."Well, to my saddened disappointment, the theme song...a song which was well composed and told the story of the series and the land that it was set in...is OMMITED!!!  In it's place for the opening sequences, is the edited instrumental that came at the end of the original shows and after the first commercial break.Very disappointing.  However, the shows are wonderful and just as I remembered.  The quality is as good as it ever was, and is still a pleasure to watch...but the "feeling" isn't quite the same as it was and I think it is all because the title song is not longer song.  Credit for this song is at the end of each series though.  I don't understand why this wonderful series now must be preserved for future generations without this theme song!  The theme song was like a portrait...telling a thousand words.  How can future generations expect to understand the portrait if it no longer exists, and therefore truly enjoy the series just as its viewers did was the series was aired?I rate the series as 5 stars and rate the theme song (as its use as a theme song)a big fat 0, thus averaging it to 3 stars.

reviewText: If you are someone like me who finally admitted to themselves that they LOVED "Here Come the Brides" (Season One) and finally decided to buy it only to find that it's now $500.00 then this review is the one you will want to read.Let's deal with the "bad news" first...(i.e. the cost and the fact that you might not get the version of the "Seattle" song you want so badly.)Why is Season One so nose-bleed expensive?  Two simple facts: 1. Sony stopped making it.  2.  Apparently in 2006 they never released that many copies anyway so it sold out really, really FAST.I will now admit that I didn't pay $500.00 for Season One.  I managed to get a USED copy that was in tolerable shape at a Sam Goody's that was closing for $18.95, which by the way was what Season One cost NEW when Sony first released it...so I didn't get much of a bargin until you consider the fact that everybody else is charging $200.00 for a used copy.Is Season One worth $500.00?  Well...although the box is cute and the packaging is superior, the actual quality of the discs are only OK.  You need to remember that between 2006 when Sony released Season One and now (2012) the quality of dubbing has improved.  By 2006 standards the picture and sound are great, by today's standards (six years later) not so great.  In fact the Season Two videos re-released by SHOUT Factory are AWESOME (way better than the Sony Season one version.)  More about SHOUT and Season Two below..but back to Season One.If you loved that opening theme like I did...you MUST realize that the VOCAL version was from SEASON TWO!!!!!!!!  Season One was an instrumental version. It's the same wonderful song by Hugo Montenegro, but ABC didn't put the vocal version into circulation until the SECOND SEASON.  Even Wikipedia gets this wrong when they state that the vocal was put in half-way through the first season...it WASN'T!!!!  If you remember the vocal from Season One, you are remembering wrong.  To make it worse, since the song got so popular some stations re-ran Season One versions where THEY actually dubbed in the song over the original instrumental, further confusing the issue.  So if you want to spend $500.00 to hear the song again...DON'T buy Season One because it's NOT there!!!!  The instrumental version however is also quite beautiful...but not $500.00 beautiful.You are now probably asking yourself is Amazon.com trying to rip you off with such a high price.  NO...look carefully at who is selling it.  These are independent dealers who have their stuff on Amazon.com.  Are these guys taking advantage of the fact that everybody wants this season...you bet.  There is nothing Amazon.com can do about this.  And before you blame these dealers you must consider that this is happening to virutally everything popular and collectable that goes out of print.  I have some martial arts books that are Paperbacks that are now worth hundreds of dollars.  I bought them back in 1978 for a couple of bucks.So what do you do if you want Season One?  There are other ways to get it, but I'd like to suggest that if you are reading this review you take the time to mobilize yourself and your friends to petition SHOUT Factory to re-release Season One.  SHOUT Factory now has the rights to the series!!!  Get enough buzz going and I'm certain they will put Season One out ASAP.  So don't get mad at Amazon.com or it's dealers...if anyone is to blame for this mess it's SONY who really didn't give a damn about the series anyway.  Instead think positive, and start getting family and friends to get SHOUT Factory to put out Season Two.Now for the good news: SHOUT Factory acquired the rights to the series and released Season Two.Although technically speaking this should be a separate review, I'm assuming that like me, you came here looking forward to buying BOTH seasons.  It's good to compare the latest version with SONY's to hopefully convince you to petition the new owners of the Series to put out Season One again.First packaging.  I will admit that compared to the original SONY version, SHOUT Factory's simpler and much more minimalist.  So packaging wise SONY is better.  However what matters is what is on the DVD.When we look at Video quality SHOUT Factory wins hands down!  The newer technology re-release is excellent compared to the now dated six-year old technology SONY used.  The colors pop, it looks great.  Sound is still something of a problem due to the 1960's technology the show originally used...but here too the newer version is clearly superior.  To sum it up, DVD wise, SHOUT factory's version blows the older SONY version away.  (But remember, we're talking Season Two here...SHOUT Factory hasn't re-released Season One, at least not yet.)Let's segue to the subject of DVD extras.  SONY really has nothing.  SHOUT Factor has interviews with Jonathan Etter, the WRITER of much of the show.  The interviews are fun and enlightening...(putting to rest once and for all that he based the show on "Seven Brides for Seven Brothers...he DIDN'T...although it's possible the producers thought he did.)So despite the fact that SHOUT Factory has more modest packaging, the quality of the videos coupled with the extras is so superior to SONY that when you buy Season Two I sincerely hope and pray that you are inspired to start petitioning SHOUT Factory to re-release Season One!"Here Come the Brides" is one of the best t.v. series ever made.  Sadly it lasted only two seasons because ABC switched it's time slot.  But it left a trememdous impression on all of us who watched.It's my hope that once you read this review you'll be inspired to get the new owners of the rights to the series (SHOUT factory) to re-release Season One.So is Season One worth $500.00?  Maybe...BUT...if you consider the fact that we might be able with pressure to get it re-released in a BETTER version than SONY's I'd think twice before I shelled out the money.  Better to get SHOUT Factory to re-release Season One in their newer, superior version with the wonderful extras than pay $500.00 for SONY's clearly inferior product.
summary: One of the BEST series ever  BUT is it worth $500.00?
Title: N/A

reviewText: I bought this because an especially fine Star Trek time travel novel was set within this show.  Bride fans--be on the lookout for Ishmael by Barbara Hambly.  It's pretty easy to find in used book stores--though be warned, the author took a few liberties with canon and Stemple is a hero!Released on the same day as The Big Valley, it's hard not to compare the two--Brides is most definitely aimed at a younger crowd, the humor is unsophisticated, and the acting isn't quite up to a Barbara Stanwyck standard.  But it's a lot of fun--there's none of syrupy, melodramatic schlock of Little House on the Prairie.  It's definitely a bit dated, but that almost helps create the 19th-century atmosphere, even if the characters are a bit too forward-thinking about some things (this is a child of the 60s!).  What surprised me is that the episodes did not progress the way I thought they would--there are plenty of cliches, of course, but lots of the stories ended differently than I thought they would--it's predictability quotient is lower than a lot of family shows.  The cast has some less than stellar moments, but they all seem so fresh and interesting, and they seem to be enjoying telling the stories--there's an innocent "let's put on a show" quality to the whole thing, it's so good-natured.  This seems like good, wholesome entertainment for keeping the kids amused on rainy days, and for the adults--a bit of nostalgia when you are home with the flu.  Candy and Biddie make good foils as the brides, the relationship between Jason and his brothers is fine, the competition between Jason and Stemple is entertaining, and I found that I especially enjoyed the relationship between Jason and Lottie (gotta love Joan Blondell!).This is good old-fashioned 60s optimism that helped balance the grimness of the anti-war movement--both attitudes were necessary and this gives you the side of the coin that lets you turn off your brain and relax.  Excellent snappy theme music and score, interesting opening credits.

reviewText: It's the 1860s, and the Bolt brothers own a big logging company in Seattle.  Their workers aren't happy, however,  because the town (population: 152) is short on women, so the Bolts decide to bring 100 marriageable young ladies all the way from Massachusetts.  They can't pay for the trip, so their arch enemy Aaron Stempel agrees to finance it on the condition that if any of the ladies leaves within a year, he gets the Bolt's timber-filled mountain.This adorable family comedy from 1968 is still as much fun as ever.  Barrel-chested Robert Brown plays the oldest Bolt brother and he's big and brawny and looks just like a lumberjack should.  David Soul is the sensitive middle brother and the youngest Bolt is played by teen idol Bobby Sherman; his character is sweet and shy and stammers.  Wonderful Mark Lenard plays the smiling villain Aaron Stempel.  With Hugo Montenegro's rousing music and gorgeous colors (the ladies' ice cream-colored dresses and the deep greens and browns of the woods), it feels more like a movie than a TV series.The show is similar in tone to "Seven Brides for Seven Brothers" with burly he-men, dainty ladies, and rip-roaring fun. Will the girls all find husbands?  Will they all stay a year?  Highly recommended.
summary: "Scent of pine trees in the air, never knew a day so fair..."

reviewText: I was only 9 when Here Come the Brides first came out but it stayed in my memory as one of my favorites over the years. I was excited to see it come out on DVD. You can't help but smile through each episode-enjoying all the characters and the storylines.  It is a great series for the whole family. It is about family, love, and new beginnings.  I loved seeing so many well known actors, too, at a very young age-like Bruce Lee. I will confess-I was (and still am) a Bobby Sherman fan!  Buying this set is a sure thing. I look forward to the second season when it is released.
summary: Great show....fun stories...finally something for everyone

reviewText: The credits at the end of the show mention the theme song, Seattle, but it is not present on any of the shows and is instead replaced by instrumental music, which is not an instrumental version of Seattle. I remember watching the show when it first aired and I remember the theme well. It was also a hit record for Perry Como. The lack of the original theme, for purists like me, mars this set. Too bad.

reviewText: When amazon first came out with season one, I purchased it right away. I had loved the show when it played the first time and seeing it again brought back so many wonderful memories. Not long before his passing, I met Mark (Arron Stimple). He was a lovely man and when I asked why the show did not run longer, he explained that there had been several times when sets had been destroyed. They more or less knew who was involved, but could never prove it. It became to expensive to re-build each time and so the show was ended.That said, along with so many others, I cannot wait for season two to come out. If you want to watch a program that will make you feel good, this is for you.

reviewText: My daughter bought me this DVD set for Mother's Day last year and it is one of my most treasured gifts. I was head-over-heels for Bobby Sherman when this series was on television. Once I opened it, I watched the entire season straight through. Some of the episodes I remembered, but through them all I smiled ear to ear. And when the show began in my DVD player I actually remembered the words to the theme song! It made me feel like this 50 year old was 11 or 12 again. The quality of each episode is amazing. The Bluest Skies might be in Seattle, but for me they are right here in North Carolina now! I hope Season 2 will be released soon.

reviewText: The instrumental-only version of the opening theme was replaced by the vocal version in mid-season.  Unfortunately, Columbia (Screen Gems), in its zeal to make the opening titles uniform when they syndicated all their 60's shows, replaced the opening on ALL episodes (first and second season) with the instrumental-only version, which apparently is where the source material sits today.  One saving grace: I remember that they missed altering one 2nd season episode... whether that "mistake" still survives will have to wait for the 2nd season DVD set.

reviewText: Being age 46, my memories of this series weren't too clear except for the original theme song, which I loved. I personally would have preferred that the makers of this collection had kept the song intact, instead of replacing it with the (in my opinion) very inferior instrumental version. I appreciate the desire for "consistency" but think "fidelity to the original production" is a better standard for DVD sets like this. That said, the show itself is fun, and what a hoot to see Bobby Sherman and David Soul in their "Brides" roles! Bridget Hanley is lovely, and her spunky character makes a good counterpoint to the rather bombastic Robert Brown (a graduate from the same acting school as William Shatner, from all appearances). You know, if "Dr. Quinn, Medicine Woman" had been intentionally played for laughs, it would have been a lot like "Here Come the Brides"...

reviewText: Wow, I am delightfully surprised this great show is being released on DVD! This was one of my very favorites shows as a kid and is one of those short-lived programs that has quite a devoted following.  Never a particularly big hit (it only ran two seasons), it was still highly entertaining and an unusual genre-bending program, equal parts drama, western, and comedy.  The show may have been a bit inspired by SEVEN BRIDES FOR SEVEN BROTHERS (and THE NAUGHTY MARIETTA) but no more than say GREEN ACRES was inspired by THE EGG AND I.HERE COME THE BRIDES is probably best remembered for the series Bobby Sherman was on when he became a major pop star but the real lead on the show was Robert Brown, a gorgeous hunk of man who was sort of a cross between Richard Burton and Robert Taylor.  There's plenty of the show to satisfy the Bobby-soxers though, and Sherman created an endearing character as the shy, stuttering youngest brother.  The wonderful veteran movie star Joan Blondell is unforgettable as saucy tavern owner Lottie and although her character is essentially a supporting one, Blondell received two well-deserved Best Dramatic Actress Emmy nominations for her work on this program.  The whole cast was terrific.  BRIDES was briefly rerun on cable in the mid 1980's but it's been basically in the vaults for twenty years now so it will be wonderful to see it again.

summary: Great even without the orginal Theme song!

reviewText: Aren't you tired of nothing BUT fans of shows from the past reviewing shows and giving them all 5 stars leaving YOU with no real perspective? Well, I am. I wasn't a fan of this show in its hay-day because I was too busy being born:) I was born in '68 but have been retracing my roots so to speak, and have uncovered a lot of gems. This could have been one. I like many of the characters and the show does show promise, I just can't get by the wacky premise. Most of the performers I like and am a Star Trek and Starsky and Hutch fan so naturaully I like Soul and Lenard, sadly, the whole aspect of this show that is "different" (finding wives, mates) I also find both unsavory and mildly uninteresting. Had this been more of a typical western with this same cast I'll bet I would have liked it more. As it stands, this is quality performances marred by a strange premise that is three steps behind any sort of reality. I'll stick with my newest "find", the Big Valley.
